description: Genericization of Launderette; originally a proprietary name (1940s) of Bendix corporation, from launder +‎ -ette.

entries.meaning: A place that has facilities for washing and drying clothes that the public may pay to use.

examples: The distinction is by no means watertight as any 'money launderette' may become a money launderer – and hence be guilty of a money laundering offence – the moment it knowingly engages in a money laundering operation.
